Award.AwardTitle: Science & Mathematics Scholars Program at a Liberal Arts College

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is designed to provide 30 need-based scholarships for academically talented undergraduates majoring in Biology, Chemistry, Computer Science, Earth and Environmental Sciences, or Mathematics at the college. Three cohorts of students are being recruited through site visits, partnerships with high schools, open houses, and electronic networking. Selection of applicants is based upon aptitude for success and interest in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). Students in each cohort live in the same residence hall, take classes together, and engage in collaborative, multidisciplinary research. Faculty and Career Services specialists are creating workshops and a network of STEM professionals to assist students with career placement. Annual surveys and interviews with recipients explore attitudes about academic support, advising, teaching, and depth of commitment to STEM careers.

Intellectual Merit: Adapting methods used in successful cohort programs at the college, the project focuses on small-group and inquiry-based learning. Improved educational opportunities include individualized mentoring, early research training, utilization of modern laboratory and computing equipment, and the use of the college marine research vessel. These opportunities provide scholarship recipients with educational experiences that leverage them into STEM related employment.

Broader Impact: This project contributes to a broad understanding of how to attract and, especially, how to retain academically talented students in STEM disciplines at a small, private liberal arts college. Recent graduates in STEM majors at the college include 18% minorities and 65% women. Thus, this project builds on a college program designed to assure the participation of historically underrepresented groups. The project culminates in a state-wide conference at the college to share findings on retention with the STEM community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The S-STEM scholarship program at Virginia Wesleyan University (VWU) provided need-based scholarships and programming for talented undergraduates majoring in Biology, Chemistry, Computer Science (CS), Earth and Environmental Sciences (EES), or Mathematics. The goals of the project were 1) to increase the number of STEM students on our campus, 2) to offer financial support to enable scholars to complete degrees in four years and 3) to provide career-building opportunities to leverage graduates in discipline-related employment or graduate school. The program included academic support in addition to financial support. Academic support included, cohort-based instruction (common classes in the first-year), close mentorship by faculty advisers, contact with STEM professionals and the opportunity for program-funded private tutoring.

 

Forty-one students participated in the program. Thirty of these STEM Scholars have graduated with STEM-discipline majors: Biology, Chemistry, Mathematics, Computer Science or Earth & Environmental Sciences (EES). Only one of these thirty took five years to complete the requirements, and one additional student plans to graduate May 2019 for a total of 31 graduates. One student transferred to another university due to a change in financial status, but remained in a STEM field (Mathematics). Four students switched to non-STEM majors and 5 left academia for personal reasons (pregnancy, health, family issues, mental health). Overall freshman-to-sophomore retention in STEM Scholars program was 66% (19/29) and slightly higher than (64%) to the overall retention rate at Virginia Wesleyan. The departing students were replaced in the program by other students at VWU who met the financial requirements and had been successful in first-year STEM classes: The Phase Two scholarship had a competitive application for replacement positions in the program because of the many eligible students at VWU.  Twelve student were selected to join the continuing students in Phase Two. All of the students who joined the program in Phase Two graduated with majors in STEM disciplines. Of the 30 graduates, 27 are pursuing further education (14) or are working in a STEM-related field (13).

 

Increased retention of ethnic minorities, women,  and financially needy students in the STEM disciplines is a major goal for the S-STEM program.  Nationally and locally, these groups have had lower retention rates in the STEM disciplines. Eighteen of our 39 participants who chose to report their race are members of minority groups: 31% Black or African American; 8% American Indian/Alaskan Native; and 8% Asian. Approximately 66% of participants were female.  A measure of financial need, the expected family contribution toward the cost of college (EFC), is calculated from the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA). This amount determines eligibility for federal aid, including S-STEM scholarships. For the 2015 academic year,.the average EFC of participants was $4972, with the majority (52%) having an EFC less than $4000. Note that the expected cost of attendance at VWU was estimated at $49,720 for 2015.

 

During the course of this project, we collected data from a group of "control" students in order to provide a comparison group to assess the effects of the special programming on our participant group. To the greatest extent possible, control participants were matched with scholarship students on the basis of gender, race/ethnicity, indicated interest in a STEM area, high school GPA, math scores, and estimated financial contribution.

 

Overall findings indicate that there were no statistically significant differences in GPA between scholarship and control students. However, participation in the scholarship program did impact student persistence in STEM areas and overall retention and graduation. At the conclusion of the study, significantly more students remained in STEM majors than did control students. Of the 41 scholarship students, 31 either graduated or were finishing their degree in STEM majors within a year. In the control group, only 11 of 30 students met that description. It is important to note that control-group students were initially matched for their interest in STEM areas; thus, the increased number of STEM scholars is likely due to participation in the program.
